review_title: Good place to do a PhD... but a PhD is grueling
job_title: PhD Candidate in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale pays its PhD students in the sciences (specifically Biology) a relatively competitive salary compared to other institutions (especially considering that the cost of living in New Haven is lower than NYC or Boston). We also get free health insurance and mental health care services which is great!
cons: As a PhD student, you work well over 40 hours a week for relatively little pay. I once averaged out how much I make hourly (given the extended hours), and I make well below minimum wage. Of course, the PhD degree itself is largely the payment for doing a PhD, but I wish that there were more perks and benefits to doing a PhD while you are in the process.

review_title: Yale University/ Yale Health Center Is Not The Same
job_title: Union Member in Hamden, CT
pros: The benefits are competitive Yale University has a vast array of career opportunities
cons: The Yale health center at Yale University use to be the best place to work when it was located on Hillhouse Ave. I use to love going to work! Since the Yale health center moved to Lock Street, It is no longer a happy, friendly, family, comfortable, safe atmosphere. The morale is at an all time low. It is not even about the patients anymore, although that is what they would love for you to believe. Yale Health in my opinion is now a corporate facility that is all about the numbers, the higher ups on the top floor, the bogus repetitive managers meetings and their nugatory research groups, the frivolous press Ganey reports, and the over populated nurses and managers that get paid a hefty amount of money for basically fudgeling at work while passing the majority of their work along to the over worked and under paid union employees, which they are trying to phase them out in an attempt to get rid of the union which is a joke anyway. There are some atrocious managers that do not even have a clue on how to manage a department and sadly treat a certain type of employees horrible, but the employees cannot say anything because if they do they will find a way to get rid of you. I want to make this clear. All of Yale University is not bad. Yale University has a vast array of career opportunities. This review is only pertaining to Yale Health Center.

review_title: Yale has perks, but it depends on whether those make you happy
job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Offers retirement, name recognition of an Ivy League school (but it's more about the PI you work for). Since Yale has a large financial endowment, some services (food, gym, product discounts) are subsidized.
cons: High taxes meaning your take home salary is significantly lower, especially as a single person.  Yale attracts a lot of intellectuals from all around the world with go-getter mentality, but they also hire from local communities (whom I believe do not respect the Yale community because of insecurities).   This rift does not blatantly confront you.  But the support staff, etc give much less energy and sometimes provide toxic environments lacking community.  This can be counter productive and frustrating if you are working in a field that requires teamwork and a lot of communication

pros:
Your type of employment union/managerial and professional dictates the type of benefits you have.
Many opportunities to learn and grow regardless of employment type through Yale programming

cons:
It really depends on your department and manager
Many layers to the system, sometimes very difficult to get anything done
Some departments are lax and others micromanage 
Some managers aren't trained but HR backs them wether they are right or wrong
Also, applying to next position is difficult even as an internal applicant. Many roles are ear marked for others with no way to know, so often you're wasting time applying.
Very long interview process. Average is 3-6 months, but I've been through a process that took a year.

job_title: Assistant Professor in New Haven, CT
pros: I have been working with the Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence for nine years and I love every aspect of my job. As educational researchers housed in the Yale School of Medicine we have a unique opportunity to conduct meaningful translational science in the service of all students and all the teachers who educate them. I have worked with the most supportive and authentic of team members and leaders who have collectively pushed us to evolve to meet the needs of school communities in real time. My mentors have been exceptionally supportive and never failed me in their support of my career growth.
cons: Applied science done well takes more time than any publication will ever do it justice. Our research in schools is time intensive and our interest in sharing results in real time to support schools and teachers to use the information effectively and support their students is much more than a 9-5. That is the nature of applied academic research.

review_title: Great for graduate students! ...if you have a good advisor
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Pay for graduate students is pretty close to the best among the Ivy League Institutions, especially considering the cost of living in New Haven. There is lots of good research going on here, and the university is well-funded enough to enable lots of great opportunities.
cons: Many of the professors are stuck in the past, which can make life pretty miserable for graduate students, depending on your advisor. Some advisors, like my own, are extremely supportive and helpful with professional growth both within and outside of academia. Others, however, have outlandish expectations for "productivity" and borderline harass their students. The administration is slow to pick up on these problems, but they will help students when prodded. However, some serious structural changes may be necessary (that the top administration are close to realizing) to reach full inclusivity.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros:
The NCPTSD - Clinical Neuroscience Research division undertakes noteworthy projects, and has a well funded research program. It provides valuable experience for junior researchers interested in psychology, psychiatry, neuroscience, and service to the veteran population.
I was fortunate to work on a multi-site project, conduct neuropsychological assessment, interact extensively with participants, and senior staff, gaining valuable experience and networking opportunities.
cons: Not unlike other clinical research, the management and cleaning of data, along with with clinical coordination and admin responsibilities can become monotonous. Still a valuable opportunity for junior/aspiring researchers in this field to get a taste of the day-to-day activities before committing to a long-term pursuit of clinical neuroscience in academia.

job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New Haven, CT
pros: This is a fabulous place to work. The people are brilliant, the work is challenging, and the mission is easy to connect with. I never have trouble finding meaning, remembering who we serve, and holding on to my “why”. The coworkers are friendly, and leadership is supportive while also providing autonomy. With time, it is possible to shape your role and new ideas are welcome. Also provides access to all the amazing benefits of Yale as a whole - auditing courses, professional development, physical and mental health supports, and mentorship.
cons: The YCEI’s work is public-facing, involving lots of interactions with people around the globe - this is mostly a pro (and one of my favorite parts) but of course there will be naysayers, so one also needs a thick skin and self-restraint not to engage them.

This is not an institution for high performers unless you are a faculty member.

review_title: Oh you have professional drive? Not here.
job_title: Finance in New Haven, CT
pros: Health benefits are wonderful, and winter recess is paid time off late December to early January each year.
cons:
If you have any professional drive or refuse to take one role and stay there until you retire, then this is not the place for you. Stay two or three years, but leave before your career hits the skids. Yale likes staff members to stay in their lanes, and simply do the job they think you should be forever grateful for having. Each staff position is only responsible for one small piece of the puzzle, so you are never really a process owner, project manager, or true subject matter expert. The result is few people, if any, in my experience, are truly well rounded and learned administrators. Plenty of Directors with dual titles that are simply not up to snuff. Lots a complacent staff who’ve been there the majority of their lives. Human Resources will tell you they love grooming in-house talent for career growth, but that doesn’t seem to be the case for most. If you’re looking to switch departments or professionally pivot, Yale HR expects you to take a demotion in job grade or even salary on occasion. Why? Because you’re lucky to be there. Or so they believe. They want you to start from scratch professionally or financially if you wish to progress.
It’s not terrible if you do your time and hit the road. Having Yale on your resume procures many an interview.

cons: Despite many changes that are happening at Yale University, many of the staff members are furiously resistant to change.  Because the benefits package is so rich, many people stay at Yale much longer than in the past.  The baby boomers on average in the country are staying for 9 additional years in the workforce.  At Yale University, the numbers must be higher since there are hundreds of employees who have been at the university for over 30 years.  Change comes slow at Yale and adapting to new technologies and better ways of doing business seem to be stalled due to the rigid mindset of many of the "lifers" who have cemented beliefs and ways of doing things.  Most high performers do not make it at Yale because they either aren't challenged in their roles or can't find the support to make much needed improvements.

job_title: Financial Analyst II in New Haven, CT
pros:
The current director has dramatically improved operations by being decisive, holding employees to high standards, eliminating duplicative and non-value added work, and cultivating a positive culture within the office. She came in during go-live of Yale's ERP implementation to a notoriously difficult position and has done wonders all things considered. She is definitely a pro to this office.

The individuals within the office are diverse and intelligent. 

Management is actively working toward improving the culture and work processes.

Yale pays 10% into the retirement (5% up-front and up to another 5% match) and also includes paid paternity leave. The salary is about average, but the total compensation package value is above most other Universities in the area.
cons:
The office frequently experiences periods of short staffing but management expects the same level of output during those times.

Upstream groups are not held accountable for not meeting deadlines. Often this office is blamed for the output and squeezed for time. This is a major driver of turnover but appears to be improving. I would have ranked Culture & Values 2 stars last year, but ranked 4 this year due to management's efforts.

Few practical training resources, although training offered by Russell Epstein indicates improvements and more options are on the way.

Paternity & maternity leave has not been updated for many years and now is average for the market (2 weeks paid Paternity, Short-term disability for Maternity which is about 10-12 weeks).

review_title: for trainees, choosing a supportive PI is important
job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New Haven, CT
pros: For graduate students and postdocs, who your advisor is will be the one factor that determines your happiness, so take time to choose wisely. (Of course, that's true for anyplace.) There are tons of smart people around, so you can always find collaborators or people to bounce ideas off of. There are many opportunities to check out seminars / events outside of your specialty. Yale has made some effort to increase professional development, at least for staff. For postdoctoral trainees, there is a postdoctoral association and other groups related to career networking (CNSPY or Biomed Career council), and outreach (Science Diplomats) you can join. There is an office of postdoctoral affairs which may be helpful depending on the situation. I have met some former postdocs who transitioned into careers in administration, and for those types of jobs Yale will often promote from within.
cons:
Some labs or research projects may be unstructured, or roles not clearly defined depending on the lab. Some labs are pressure cookers (shouldn't be a surprise at a place like Yale). There is a lot of bureaucracy dealing with grants, probably similar to other research universities I'm sure, but sometimes it's out of control.

The office of career strategies (where you go for help with job searching) is currently undergoing restructuring and it seems postdocs and grad students are low on the totem pole. Of course, undergrads are the ones paying tuition in part for that but hopefully there will be staff hired who will be dedicated to these populations.

job_title: Postgraduate Research Associate in New Haven, CT
pros:
- Access to great lectures, seminars and talks.
- Many great mentors and leaders in their field - good for creating relationships for mutual benefit.
- External perception of a Yale job is positive and will make you stand out when moving on.
- New Haven is a nice little town.
- There is no official policy on holidays, work hours etc, which can either work out positively or negatively, based on your PI and your own personal work ethic/discipline/disposition etc.
cons:
- This particular position offers little benefits, and low pay - you are not tied to any union or provided extra benefits, such as being a research assistant. This is despite doing pretty much the same job as research assistants, in terms of work load, projects, expectations etc.
- There is no formal structure of mentorship - you have to get lucky if there are people in your lab willing to teach you.
- PIs can be rather absent, and there is not much accountability, progress management or reporting.
- Internal politics of labs have been known to be detrimental to work environment.

review_title: Yale - need to take hold of the experience and make it your own.
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher  in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale offers great exposure to great minds and great resources. My experience derives from a fairly narrow existence in the department of ecology and evolutionary biology. Nonetheless, I have been impressed with the lab facilities, libraries, etc. As in any academic setting, I have freedom to explore and guide the outcome of various different facets of my project. There is also ample opportunity to train and work with students and technicians. And of course, I have a great deal of flexibility in work hours. As far as environment, New Haven is a beautiful place to live in the spring and summer.
cons: I have few complaints regarding Yale as an employer. As with all institutions, a substantial bureaucracy exists to hamper even the most trivial of tasks. Each lab and department has its own culture, and at least some come across as fairly impenetrable to the outsider. This goes for the city as well. New Haven is a small town trying to be bigger than it really is. More Bridgeport than New York or Boston. Winter is cold and rainy and restaurants are expensive. Although several neighborhoods are quite comfortable, many leave a lot to be desired. Oh, and much of the Yale gym is ancient.

job_title: PhD Student in New Haven, CT
pros: a solitary and warm community
cons: the stipend is not very high

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros: Love it. Great experience love it.
cons: Nothing. Cafeteria. Expensive. Love it.

job_title: Graduate Student in New York, NY

job_title: Grader in New Haven, CT
pros: Good pay, reasonable work load

job_title: Associate Director in New Haven, CT

review_title: Review of Major Gifts Development, Yale University
job_title: Development Officer, Major Gifts in New Haven, CT
pros:
Team of major gifts officers is a good one (except 1 of 16 officers leaves approx every 6 months). 
Good work/life balance
iPads
Department is willing to train fundraisers and take persons from non-traditional careers.
Office centrally located downtown next to the Green.
cons:
Pay is not competitive with other Ivies or the regional market.
Promotion system is far from transparent - not directly related to results. Pay at various title levels equally opaque.
If you are male, you will never hold a management position within this 250-person  organization under its current leadership (accept it unfortunately).
Entire development office works on intense systems of micromanagement

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros:
Intellectually stimulating: the ideas and theories about health systems flowed freely.  
Schedule: spent most of the time in a 9-5 setting, with some very interesting travel.
Interaction with students: the best and brightest continually inspired our office with their vivaciousness and critical thinking skills.  
Retirement: the 403(b) plan 5% match with a 5% bonus is a very good retirement package.
Yale: the greater community is great!  Lots of wonderful people to meet who possess a diversity of experiences and knowledge bar none.
cons:
Directors: The directors of the office where I worked were terrible.  It was their way or the highway in terms of considering ideas and the way forward.
Resistant to change: The group I work mainly duplicated efforts already existing in the private and public sector without much difference.  This led to a lack of belief in the mission on my part.
Favoritism: Directors conspicuously chose favorites, hailing their smallest feats as ground-breaking and actively criticizing the employees who they did not like.

review_title: Where you work defines your experience.
job_title: Graduate Research Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros: Having the Yale brand on your resume is a terrific life-long asset. Generally the staff are very helpful. While my day -to-day life often felt isolated, I enjoyed my experiences with various student groups, seminars, etc. Also, the Graduate Career Resource Center is incredible. They invite top consulting firms, host resume workshops, dissertation boot camps, and invite guest speakers from inside and outside academia so you know all your options when you graduate. It's entirely up to you to get out there and make the most of your time at Yale.
cons: As a graduate researcher, my day-to-day life felt very isolating. My once large and thriving lab shrunk considerably in size as people graduated and funding dried up. I found that un-tenured professors are usually very stressed out and can overwork their students. On the flip side, tenured professors are way too laid back and don't move fast enough on publications, grant proposals, etc. Choose your mentor wisely, and be sure to change mentors early on if things look like they're not working out.

job_title: Director in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale hosts an incredible array of events and training opportunities. You truly get to learn from and interact with global leaders in all kinds of fields. The campus is beautiful and the resources immense.
cons:
Many people in my area have very poor work life balance. Although there are many resources, because of cutbacks almost 1000 support positions have disappeared in the last few years and many people are now overworked. Simultaneously, there are many people duplicating work because they fear redundancy. The unwillingness to collaborate results in a very competitive atmosphere, were individuals become territorial  and there is an incredible lack of efficiency.

The atmosphere of competition creates a sense of isolation. This is especially unfortunate because there are enormously talented people at Yale and the potential for innovation in Higher Education is huge, if only people would work together more.

review_title: Pretty Good Pay. Don't Get Poisoned
job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Pretty friendly environment, healthcare, grad student events, for most grad schools, the pay is good. If they poison you, they'll stop actively trying for a while, (but good luck getting your long term health taken care of. The doctors Yale supplies want to say that it's not Yale's fault and will recommend most other solutions to say it isn't Yale's fault).
cons: They're looking to save a buck. If that means not replacing water pipes until it's too late and half the graduate students are lead poisoned, and then still not replacing the pipes but explain that it's simply that the water wasn't used enough by the thousand people that go through the building every day, whatever. Life happens. Also, political wrongthink is not allowed. You will embrace far left ideology, but that's more the environment. What do you expect, it's Yale.

job_title: Lecturer/Part-time in New Haven, CT
pros: The students are some of the smartest and most talented that I have ever met. The staff are like  family. We know each other well and we support each other and help each other. It's a pleasure to come to work. The job is exactly what you would expect - you teach, you hold office hours, you grade papers, etc.
cons: New Haven isn't really a city in which you can raise a family. Most staff and faculty live in other towns and drive in. The homelessness rate is high, and there are a lot of muggings and petty crime incidents. The part-time contract means that you may not have guaranteed employment for more than a few months at a time, and often the job falls through at the last minute due to low student enrollment or the department giving the course to permanent faculty or graduate students.

job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros:
-- nice and friendly colleagues, not at all competitive
-- University life is fantastic.
-- microscopy facilities, machine shops and other shared labs  have  first class equipment and they let you use everything you need for a reasonable fee.
-- libraries are great
cons:
-- graduate classes are useless, professors have no interest in teaching them and you can see it.
-- in general, there is no planning whatsoever when it comes to research. Most PIs (I have talked to my colleagues to know about their stories) are too busy looking for money rather than making good use of it. No point in discussing how to do better, nobody listens.
-- as a graduate student your time has no value. The more they waste, the more they ask. It is up to you to put a limit to it.
-- good feedback is polite, rational, specific, and if necessary, also very strict. In general feedback does not go beyond the following: "this is not enough!, work more!!". Not very useful.

job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Great benefits.  Hard to get fired for any reason.  Taking care of the disadvantaged of New Haven.  Faculty are very talented and world changing discoveries happen frequently.
cons: Hard to get fired for any reason - dead wood accumulates.  People not leaving and little upward mobility at the higher levels creats significant logjams for entry level managers.  People get frustrated and buy into the no change attitude - sucking up the benfits till they retire.  Union pay scale so high that there are secretaries working for 10 years that can make $5,000 more than front line managers and they are eligible for overtime pay (which they can get if they are aggressive regardless of the need).

review_title: Good people, good challenges, and good benefits...
job_title: Summer Intern in New Haven, CT
pros: People are the best thing about Yale University: they are dedicated, hardworking, and for the most part, friendly and professional. They also take on much more work they one can possibly handle in a 40 hours/week job. Management is, for the most part, supportive of IC's initiatives, as long as they don't get in the way of the normal course of business. Benefits are excellent, and there is so much going on at Yale that it is easy to spend a lot more time on campus than you would in other work environments.
cons: Management is somewhat inconsistent at leading people, and the decision making process can be quite lenghty because of long established organizational politics. In that wake, the work environment turns poisonous and people lose motivation--normally just temporarily. As long as you know how handle those situations, you should be fine; otherwise, expect long days and lots of anxiety.

job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New Haven, CT
pros: Access to library resources, facilities, talent.  High quality infrastructure for science, lots of activities on campus.  Being affiliated with Yale lends credibility, respect from outsiders.  Reasonable benefits package but doesn't totally make up for the poor salary.  Although New Haven has its detractors, it is a major population center with plenty of amenities, easy access to big cities in the Northeast.
cons: Low salary, insular, bureaucratic, egos. Associate Research Scientist (ARS) is an odd category that is technically faculty but looked down up by professors; it is always hard to explain to people both on and off campus what the appointment means.  There are relatively few ARS on campus so limited peer group, hard to get moral support in difficult times.  Too difficult to move up the non-tenure ranks.  Considering experience and skills ARS pay is a bad joke.

review_title: Great benefits, not so great administration
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: The benefits can't be beat. The health insurance, paid time off, sons and daughters scholarship program, homebuyers assistance program...all stellar
cons: The university leadership is trying to corporatize a research university. While on some level this is necessary, on a human scale it is horrible in its implementation and rationality. Bad leaders beget bad leaders... Metrics are now universally and most incorrectly used across the university for staffing decisions, facilities decisions, and lots more, leading to  department and university leaders thinking they're certified statisticians. It's a horrible, toxic environment

job_title: Accountant in New Haven, CT
pros: Job isn't as stressful as public sector but Yale isn't the same place it used to be and is getting more and more corporate.  Benefits are ok but getting worse.  Raises are minimal < 3%.  The work is interesting and it is cool to work for a University.
cons: A good thing is ruined by a bad Director and Yale has lots of them.  Too much drama/internal conflict and less focus on the work.  Paying for parking sucks.  There is a HUGE difference between union workers who get 3% raise no matter what and M&P workers who have to pick up the slack.  HR is pretty clueless and Yale takes care of those at the top and at the bottom but the middle guys get squeezed.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Great research, amazing genomic sequencing center. The stipend is easily top 5% in the country especially after adjustment for cost of living. Community of graduate students is good and highly supportive, lots of extra opportunities for career development on campus if you're proactive and look for them.
cons: Mostly due to the fact that academia has been slow to adjust to a new job environment, the advising from faculty on nonacademic job avenues is poor, and the career services are limited to nonexistent. There are some great student led career based training for consulting which place a number of students every year. Dental/Vision could be better, but over all the healthcare is pretty good for graduate programs.

review_title: Good starter job, move on for your career
job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Great educational opportunities, great co-workers, great benefits package.
cons: No room for growth or upward mobility, nepotism  or favoritism, expected to work 10-20 hours past the 40 hours per week salaried, immense pressure if you do not work up to this standard.  Constant reorganization of job duties to ensure productivity with added duties each time an update is made.  One person does the job of 2-3 people.  Those who do not contribute to the work environment are not held accountable if they have personal preference with the administration.  Scapegoating and bullying if you do not agree with these practices.

review_title: If you are not super into academia, DON'T GO THERE.
job_title: Software Developer in New Haven, CT
pros: Job security, health insurance, HR, generous sick days and holidays.
cons:
I usually don't write reviews if it is bad, but I had to this time. I worked at Peabody museum, and it had all the bad things I could experience. It is place for old people or students basically. I needed a recovery time from what I experienced after I quit.

Basically, I met the worst manager in my life who didn't want to communicate, review my code, test my work, and involve in any of development process even though it is his project. Also, the salary was so low that my previous employer paid more than what I made from Yale after annual raise. Peabody didn't care about isolated staffs. They tried to look like they care, but they didn't at all. I barely was able to talk to people.

job_title: Grad Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Amazing resources and support. The lifestyle of a graduate student at Yale was amazing. I knew early on that I didn't want to stay in academia but grad school was so much fun that I stuck with my research. There are tons of cultural, professional, social, and educational (not just in your field of study) resources. And the academics (varies by department) of my department were top notch.
cons: New Haven isn't for everyone. It had plenty for me, but it's not a big city and there are a limited number of bars and cafes and such so for the 5-7 years of grad school you will be frequenting the same places.

review_title: It's exciting to be around so many smart people
job_title: Director in New Haven, CT
pros: beautiful campus; very smart and talented undergrads, grads, and professional school students; world-renowned faculty; cutting-edge research; amazing resources available to the Yale community and Yale affiliates
cons: low pay compared to industry; administration moves very slowly; campus is safe but the surrounding areas are not very safe so one has to always be on alert, especially when walking home at night; bureaucracy

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Good benefits and Sick time and Paid time off. Met a lot of good people and learned a lot in my career there.
cons: It's not what it once was. This used to be a great place to work, but IT management needs to be reorganized or replaced. Seems like everyone has their own agenda and do just enough to appease their manager. Poor communication between departments leads to lackluster results. No room for advancement. You could be stagnant for a long time in a position unless you get lucky and someone likes you enough to give you a shot. Hard work is not rewarding and staff development is non-existent unless to you like watching useless online videos (Lynda.com) as training. There are better places out there that truly care about staff development.

review_title: The HR function at Yale University is extremely dysfunctional and lacks good leadership.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Prestigious Ivy League University with cutting edge research facilities, a beautiful campus and a wide variety of social activities available.
cons: Opportunities for advancement are often influenced by cronyism and preferential treatment, as opposed to a more objective evaluation of an individual's ability to perform effectively in a role. There is very ineffective management and leadership within many of the departments throughout the University, as people are hired into these roles or promoted without having the requisite managerial skills needed in order to be successful.

review_title: Great Science, OK salary, Poor Safety
job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New Haven, CT
pros:
Great paid time-off and generous vacation time - but it really depends on PI 
 Good benefits 
 World Class Research Environment - almost can find any subject that is under study 
 Smart and efficient people to see and learn from them 
 Faculty - Mostly leading fields and well-recognized, easy to connect and ensure research
quality
cons:
Pressure - demanding working environment, very easy to be nervous or unhappy
Long working hours are taking granted - often exhausted people found 
Salary - not really great in the name of being at Yale 
Poor safety measure - got improved but still a lot to work on in many areas 
Staff - Lots of variations and usually expected to be slow.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Being part of the Yale community opens up a lot of opportunities for networking and job searching. Get involved with groups like CNSPY and BCC to find like-minded people who share your career goals. Transportation around New Haven is made easy by the free shuttle system provided by Yale.
cons:
Every part of Yale is perpetually under construction of some kind. Also, you need to take an active role in your own safety when walking around New Haven.
Compensation is substantially lower than an industry postdoc position.

review_title: Fair place to work and they'll reward hard work
job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Time off is a great benefit.  For those who are career minded there a endless opportunities to advance in management. Child tution benefit is wonderful as is their 403K retirement plan.
cons: They never close in bad weather and it makes it dangerous for those who travel from out of town and don't support the student body. Health insurance is expensive if your not in a union or using the yale health plan. Parking is also expensive and many lots are not paved.  Fortunately they do have security escorts.  Equity between union workers and M&P's needs to be improved. On site child care not very easy to use.

review_title: Still a pretty good place to work
job_title: Assistant Manager in New Haven, CT
pros: .Educational institution, interesting students and faculty, job activities can vary greatly day to day, week to week and month to month, I spend my day (mostly) helping people
cons: From the perspective of my job, it feels like the institution is becoming more corporate and is losing the focus on education and training.  The business practices are cumbersome, not communicated clearly, and situations for discrete populations aren't consistently and clearly addressed.

job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: I have had nothing but good experiences at Yale University thus far. Admin is very amiable and willing to work with you to accomplish goals. They really make the PhD a custom degree tailored to your own research questions.
cons: I have experienced few downsides or cons at Yale thus far. Teaching courses is a bummer, but that's bound to be a thing no matter where you go. Thankfully, Yale only requires 1 year of teaching fellowship.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: You get all the resources to do your research. A lot of funding involved; lots of networking event and courses to meet people and develop a career. Great supporting offices (international students, career development). Aim at groups with startups and patents rather than number of publications.
cons: Too much funding. PIs are focused on getting more and more and boost their ego instead of efficiently route their resources (so many projects started and never carried on). Very little collaboration with other groups so they don't share the success. The groups with a different modus operandi get their things done and have startups and patents in their portfolio.

review_title: Chill in the good and bad sense
job_title: Office of Sustainability Student Worker in New Haven, CT
pros: You are allowed to bill for the silliest things, work is generally fun, lots of outdoors time, cool team structure. Yale has a lot of resources and will give you access to them if you have an moderately difficult to implement but risk-free proposal for how to raise awareness or encourage recycling or whatever.
cons: Little work gets done, bureaucracy crushes most attempts at real innovation, students managing students generally doesn't work, no opportunity for advancement or real quotable experience.

job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale offers phenomenal science faculty to work with who are all working on incredibly interesting projects.  Moreover, there is a breath of mentoring styles amongst the faculty, meaning that, through rotations, it is very easy to find the right lab for you.
cons: Many people take issue with New Haven.  It is absolutely a real urban environment, and not a tourist-trap urban environment.  This means that you must actually pay attention and keep yourself safe.  The usual caveats of "don't walk alone at night" apply, just as they would apply anywhere.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Good benefits. Opportunities to get involved and give back to the community. Staff affinity groups for women, ethnic minorities, and LGBT.
cons: The experience of working at Yale depends on the specific department. Even HR is decentralized. Do your research. Look online for old news stories or lawsuits in that dept. Look for signs of high turnover versus long-term employees. Speak to people who used to hold that position. Departments like the Library, Yale Press, Graduate School, and some academic departments, have earned reputations for interpersonal conflict. Many of the individual graduate and professional schools have reputations for happy staffers.

job_title: Postgraduate Research Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale is the perfect place to start a scientific career. I had access to amazing mentors, and amazing resources: free shuttles, an incredible library, beautiful architecture, a fully outfitted makerspace/engineering lab, the list could go on forever.
cons: It is my understanding that the compensation is less than at many other RA jobs, but then again so is the cost of living here in New Haven. Yale is just perpetuating the trend: pay academics as little as possible.

job_title: Program Administrator in New Haven, CT
pros: As a top research and education institution, Yale has a wide array of opportunities for its staff to get engaged in the culture and community.
cons: Advancement priority given to staff that have Yale degrees, salary negotiations limited with little acknowledgement to prior work experience, all authority for approvals held by senior leaders rather than delegating to qualified staff, very limited training for system wide financial software platforms and policies with an emphasis for "learn as you go from those around you" rather than a centralized training program to ensure consistancy

review_title: Good place to work, great place to retire.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Great benefits, time off, and relative stability
cons: Complacency, inept leadership, a low regard (financially) for managerial and professional staff and despite the name, there isn't anything groundbreaking being done here outside of academia and medicine.  Administrative staff are certainly the bottom rung and it is felt.  Most people can't/won't leave because of the golden handcuffs - amazing benefits, time off and it's likely paying for their children's college education.

review_title: Associate Research Scientist: Interesting work and great benefits
job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New Haven, CT
pros: I think the benefits (retirement plans, health care, etc.) are excellent.  I pay only $20/mo for health care for my family and myself.  Yale has very good matching for their 403b retirement plan - take advantage of it - it's free money!  When I had children I was given what I considered sufficient time off work.  I also enjoy my work, it's interesting.  And I work with excellent, intelligent people.  There's always something happening at Yale (talks, music, theater) and lots of good eating places nearby.
cons: I can't think of any.  I really love working at Yale.

review_title: Okay but have a Plan B
job_title: Program Coordinator in New Haven, CT
pros:
+ Prestige 
+ Salary
+ Benefits
+ The paychecks do not bounce
+ Generous time off
+ Culture of hard work, excellence. 
+ Good for high achievers
cons:
- Can get canned for no reason or justification
- They love to hide behind "at-will" employment. 
-  No real tuition reimbursement plan
-  Little/no job security for staff - a "reorg" or "funding issues" can come up anyday. This happens more than senior management admits.
- Bosses are too afraid to stand up to higher-ups

review_title: Yale is a great place for graduate students
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Wheat Ridge, CO
pros: I love the people that I work with; very friendly, tight community within the School of Engineering and Applied Science. Additionally, as Yale is a small school, you very quickly meet everyone in engineering. Everyone is very wiling to help you achieve your goals in whatever capacity that they can.
cons: Very minimal options for coursework, as the school is very small. As a graduate student, you are unfortunately expected to work extensive hours (60+) to accomplish what is necessary for your PhD thesis. As a graduate student, pay is low, as expected, but it's truly wonderful that as graduate students, we can get paid to go to school!

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros: The people are the are probably the greatest thing about this place. Everyone is welcoming, smart, helpful, and easy going. The Ivy league attitude is not an issue here, at least among the bio grad school students and profs.
cons: Surprisingly, maintenance of buildings, computer connection, etc. is very inefficient. OML building in particular seems to be left behind with respect to upgrades and general working environment upkeep. Takes forever to get anything fixed - light bulbs, wireless, cubicles, ... . Seems that there is no structure regarding maintenance.

job_title: Student Manager-Dining Hall in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale obviously hires a lot around the New Haven area, but if you are a student looking to make easy money on the side without cutting too much into your schoolwork and social life, I highly recommend applying to be a student manager at one of the dining halls.
cons: The only downside I can think of doesn't really apply to students: there's limited room for growth within the employment system at Yale, but then again why would you want there to be? You're job will be ending within in the year anyway.

review_title: Communications officer / Management & Professional staff member
job_title: Communications in New Haven, CT
pros: Great environment -- smart people, stimulating, lots of free lectures and talks by anyone you can imagine. Excellent benefits. though some are being phased out or lessened for new employees
cons: It's very decentralized and can be frustrating. If you are looking for everything to make sense and be orderly, that will depend on how cohesive and well run your own work unit is. Lots of variation in the quality of the management. Very good senior leadership but not focused on understanding and motivating staff (as opposed to faculty). Mobility is difficult once you rise in the ranks.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: The pay is about a year behind the NIH fellowship.  The cost of living is lower than comparable institutions.  The Yale Health plan is fantastic.  You can contribute to regular and Roth 403b plans, but there is no matching for post docs.  There are other tax deferred benefits for dependent care, commuting, etc. ,but you will loose access to these the years that you have a fellowship.  They are expanding their career services programs for postdocs and graduate students.
cons: If you get a fellowship you will loose access to all of your benefits other than health insurance, but this is standard at just about any institution.

review_title: Great benefits but you must have a thick skin
job_title: Waitstaff in New Haven, CT
pros: Benefits, pay, some of the people you meet. They give you family meals for most every shift that you work and it isn't a TV dinner. It is very good food that you are fed.
cons: Some of the people are not so nice and can be very lazy. If people have a job already they just say it is not their job and the contracted workers must do it to get the job done.

job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: The school is amazing with a beautiful campus. The size of the undergrad enrollment is small,  so it offers a smaller class size that allows for better interactions among students and faculties.
cons: The hours for the gym and the dinning hall are somewhat less compare to other universities, where the gyms can sometime open for 24 hours. At Yale, the gym close really early during weekdays and open couple hours during the weekend. The dinning hall closes around 7PM each day. So it is not convenient.

job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Best health insurance plan, do not have to pay premium, Yale health system is comprehensive, doctors are excellent, most important, the coverage of the health insurance is much better than other private insurance company.
cons: High competition, faculty there is excellent and you will feel huge pressure when all your colleagues are excellent. You have to fight for your research grant which basically cover your salary and there is no basic salary the school will provide, except the first several years for start up.

review_title: Great benefits, not much room for promotion"
job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Job security (Union) and benefits, paid time off.
cons: Little room for upward mobility as a clerical & technical employee, especially if you work in research. Here often a good worker is only rewarded with more work, not a higher paycheck...due to "budgetary restraints"

review_title: life as a post doc at Yale
job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Fantastic research resources, very intelligent and kind colleagues, collaborations are easy to come by and establish, incredible medical school. The postdoctoral population is very diverse. Health care is very good. Pay is about average, and although Yale explicitly states that salary is non-negotiable I've found that to be untrue.  Name recognition is very high. I
cons: Poor resources for postdocs transitioning towards faculty positions, reflects in a large wash out. New Haven is a bit on the rough side. The demands of being a faculty at Yale often outweigh the desire to be a good mentor.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros: The people in postdoctoral affairs were very helpful in mediating and compensating me for the abuse I endured under my postdoc mentor. Postdocs are not At-Will employment and mentors must detail why your performance is lacking and then give you reasonable time to improve. While that a benefit because my mentor could not fire me she instead resorted to abusing and making me miserable until I quit from overwhelming stress and anxiety.
cons:
My postdoctoral mentor, I write with no exaggeration, was possibly a sociopath with bipolar tendencies. She believed people either to be 100% good or entirely bad. There was little to no in between with her.

 It only took doing a few things to displease her to fall into to entirely bad category. For me it was insistence to work on hypothesis driven projects with good potential to produce a publication. 
 
What I did not know was my mentor is basically a statistician  dabbling in biological research for fun. She had no need to publish as her funding came in the form of a gift from the known family of drug pushers for Oxycontin. 

Once I had fallen into the bad category, she attempted to ruin me entirely. She covertly transferred my projects to other lab members, and had my mouse colony I had been breeding for a future project entirely euthanized, a project for which she had already planned for and had protocols. In addition to all that she told nasty lies about me to other lab members. She also lied to me and told me everyone in the lab hated me. When I suggested having an open discussion to address issues she became frantic yelled at me and insisted the issue not be addressed. I did try to address people to try to mediate any issues and found that the issues were entirely lies.

That was pretty bad, but things really took a turn when I was falsely accused of research misconduct and then banned from the university on the basis of mental health issues, which I had never discussed with my mentor at all. The university should be ashamed for discrimination on unfounded lies about a persons mental health status.

Ultimately I was cleared on any wrong doing in a nearly half year investigation and compensated given that the abuse had forced me to resign from my position.

job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: You get to work for the brightest minds; intellectually challenging environment; research facilties are superb. Having a Yale stamp on your resume pays dividends in the long run. Career options after Yale are also great. The career services office helps out students a lot by inviting top notch companies for recruitment.
cons: New Haven is not a great town, it gets boring at times. Every so often there is a mugging incident, even in nicer neighborhoods. Winters can be bad and can get very depressing. The health plan offered to graduate students is not so flexible. University housing for graduate students is also limited.

review_title: A real opportunity for work while a student.
job_title: Bass Media Tech in New Haven, CT
pros: An opportunity to work with peers in a world class institution that offers great pay for a part time job and the opportunity to meet peers and be productive as well.
cons: While it is tough to manage a 19 hour max work week while being a student, that is usually expected. The negative might be to do with management and how they view the busy lifestyle at times when the job is not a priority.

review_title: With lots of perks comes a lot of unchecked privilege.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Great benefits (health coverage especially), beautiful campus, exciting research, distinguished environment, brilliant minds.
cons: Lots of out of touch white old guys. The issue isn't necessarily that they're rich, or old, or white, but out of touch. They're trying to work on it.

review_title: Yale is no longer as great as it once was.  The administrative structure must be reorganized if it is going to survive.
job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: The benefits are amazing and it is the best place to work in CT.
cons: They are still in the past and need to think about the future.  This is a school that has been around longer than the federal government, and I can guarantee that it has more bureaucracy than the federal government.

review_title: Yale administration  is a cemetery for minds to die
job_title: Safety Advisor in New Haven, CT
pros: Good benefits atleast on paper ;  free food;  training opportunities though they come laced with strings,  Yale name brand on your CV.
cons: Working at Yale's Environmental health and Safety has been my single most bitter professional experience so far.  Its only after leaving Yale, I realized how much professionally I was setback.  Added to this is the corrosive effect of prejudice in the form of micro-aggressions that I had to encounter on a daily basis.  Complaining to HR is a big joke   and they clearly are in bed with the managers.

review_title: Yale - a great place to  work
job_title: Coordinator in New Haven, CT
pros: Stimulating people, entrepreneurial envronment, open to speaking yr mind; opportunities to learn from the best, the ability to move around and gain new knowledge.
cons: the work keeps increasing but the pay is not commensurate. The introduction of a new pay for performance program lessens the ability of supervisors to praise and recognize hard work by introducing arbitrary numerical ratings that are linked to pay.  Many front line supervisors, faculty and staff, are untrained and inept Pretty inflexible management policies.

review_title: Lab is great, support staff is horrible.
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros: There are a lot of career development opportunities. The Pharmacology department is very interested in scientific developments and most of the PI are open about various career paths other than academia. There is also a lot of collaboration so it is a very good place for scientific development.
cons: Fighting the bureaucratic network is a nightmare. You are actually punished when you get a fellowship as Yale will no longer pay for your healthcare, you have to pay the entire premium. The is often a disconnect between the Yale HR and the departmental HRs making salary or title changes a difficult transition.

review_title: Great place to work, terrible city to live in
job_title: Development Associate, Principal Gifts in New Haven, CT
pros: Large, prestigious institution provides a lot of security and support; great benefits and pay compared to other kinds of nonprofits; helping to educate tomorrow's leaders; lots of smart people around
cons: High turnover rate (at least in Development), passive-aggressiveness, HR not particularly helpful in conflict situations, not much investment in career development

review_title: More Like a Corporation Than a University.
job_title: IT Support Technician II in New Haven, CT
pros:
Yale has great benefits from time off to healthcare.  

Many people are impressed to hear that you work at Yale.  

There are elements here and there who listen to feedback and make real improvements.
cons:
You rapidly reach a point (depending on the job) where you can't advance any farther.  It is very difficult to get promotions and to move from one job to another (with exceptions in a few areas.)  HR has procedures, which make it sound easy but actual results are disappointing.  You end up with very little change and can't really get anywhere without leaving the university.  

There is a great deal of inertia in many areas.  This is often mistaken for bureaucracy but the rules and procedures really aren't that bad.  I attribute it more to poor motivation.  The situation with promotions tends to select for employees who don't care much and don't do much.   Middle managers are encouraged to cut bureaucracy but there is a fine line between cutting bureaucracy and thinking you're above the rules.  

There are too many separate classifications of employees.  The M&P and C&T classifications are a lot like officers vs. enlisted in the military.  They have the same kinds of similar job titles (assistant vs. associate and technician vs. specialist.)

review_title: Great organization, but conservative and slow-moving
job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale offers great salaries and benefits, intelligent colleagues and faculty, and upward mobility. My department also encourages continued learning and access to some of the most interesting speakers and events that come to campus.
cons: Yale is hindered by it slow-moving, conservative culture. Though faculty are doing amazing work here, the institution as a whole does not foster the innovative, entrepreneurial culture that you could find elsewhere (Stanford, MIT, etc.).

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Benefits are good, time is flexible, employer perks are good.  Co-workers are generally educated, helpful and friendly.
cons: Conflicts with union sometimes overshadow issues.  Working with other departments is sometimes difficult.  Budgets have been cut for departments.  Med school relies on grant funding for many processes.

review_title: Limited advancement for Clerical and Technical employees
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Benefits are great, and salary is fairly good.
cons: Limited to no advancement for Clerical and Technical employees. Yale would rather hire from outside sources than develop and advance anyone from a C&T position.  Once a "senior administrative assistant" you are stuck there for life.

review_title: Library positions offer well-paid, flexible jobs for students, with some opportunity for promotion
job_title: Student LIbrarian in New Haven, CT
pros:
At Sterling Memorial Library, student jobs have very flexible hours
Supervisor is understanding and inspires students to get involved in the mission of the library
Some opportunity for promotion (and accompanying raises) to semi-managerial role
cons:
Main tasks in Access Services, like shelving and accuracy checks, can be monotonous over long periods of time
Promotion decisions are somewhat arbitrary and dependent on student attrition rates

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in New Haven, CT
pros: Cares about undergraduates, provides state of the art facilities (in most cases). Recognized world wide for academic grandeur. Competitive pay for graduate schools which is enough to get by in the surrounding area. Access to great healthcare, though dental and eye is extra. Proficient transportation system, but great police force. Hires locals for many support positions
cons: Seems to care more about bottom line than what is good for departments and students. Yale, although an excellent school, has become populated with managers and assistants that run institutes that are based on the amount of grant money brought in, and not necessarily what a group needs. So although still academic, the University is now designed as a more corporate entity, which focuses on finances, made apparent in the fact that 65% of the grants go to the general fund. The university also will waste copious amounts of money in construction projects where better planning could have saved thousands of dollars (moving the NMRs three times in one year instead of once and each move was $10000 per instrument). The graduate student experience varies in department and lab, but in general, graduate students seem to be undervalued (as is typical with most universities). The medical eye and dental insurance (additional fee) only covers the bare minimum, and in the case of contact wearers, only $104 per year for contact lenses - exam not covered.  Also, parking fees for employees/students is ridiculous considering the lots are owned by the University. Facilities staff seem uninterested in job and in doing bare minimum. The floors in the labs are only swept and mopped if requested, which is usually never.

job_title: Faculty in New Haven, CT
pros: In the past, was a good workplace. Union and administration relations were cordial and there hadn't been a major strike in over ten years.
cons: People are being laid off or retired and not replaced. Future direction is uncertain given that much of the union labor force is being outsourced (to centralized food production or to business workpools). Atmosphere is much chillier than in previous years.

job_title: Doctoral Candidate in New York, NY
pros: Access to very smart people, great library system, competitive graduate stipend, flexibility in teaching requirements
cons: Expensive living costs, low turnover/most professors should have been retired long ago, little guidance professionally, large gap in services provided to humanities vs. sciences, no student feedback, poor preparation from school in areas of teaching/administrative service, poor outreach for grad students looking for non-academic careers

job_title: Chinese Tutor in New Haven, CT
pros: I'm a student so I'm only discussing student jobs. There are very diverse positions! Some are more technical than others, but overall great choices for everyone!
cons: I've only worked two jobs, one as a Chinese language tutor, and the other as a research assistant for the MacMillan Center for Area Studies. So i'm not really in a position to judge!

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Terrific Benefits and PTO.  There are so many different field to work in and the campus is beautiful. Regular raises. I enjoyed the Academic environment.  There were learning opportunities every day.
cons: Not a lot of room for advancement.  Clerical staff are treated as in a different class of person by some members of management and the Professors.  Students can be arrogant.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Excellent Pay, Excellent Benefits, Some great manager and supervisors. A lot of time off. Flexible schedules when need be.
cons: Some departments are a definite ' who you know' not what you know department in terms of moving up. Very little Supervisor/Employee conversations over quality of work.  Hard to move up. Managers and Leads have their favorites.  The Work/Life balance could be a bit better.

review_title: Yale is a great place to work for higher ed staff/administrative professionals.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: A strong culture of excellence & success; great health and retirement benefits; excellent soft perks (e.g., access to libraries and other institutional resources).
cons: Some offices could benefit from more active professional development (of skills, review of best practices, etc.); but this is not unique to Yale.

review_title: Perhaps, one day, we will remember even these things fondly.
job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale provides a wonderful set of resources to its graduate students : fantastic libraries, great benefits, excellent career counseling and a great brand name after graduation.
cons:
Graduate school ultimately for me became a very solitary research enterprise with minimal meaningful impact. Graduate school told me all the reasons I don't want to be in academia.
Living in New Haven isn't for everyone. I liked it, but come with the right mindset.

review_title: I have not made the progress that is needed due to cultural resistance to change.
job_title: Management in New Haven, CT
pros: Management can be influenced with carefully prepared metrics and arguments, though this is costly to do for all proposals and projects. There are good benefits and relatively good job security.
cons: Common business efficiency objectives are not uniformly held. Academic freedom is touted as a birthright, but it seems irrelevant for non-academics. Back office staff really should focus on optimizing operations and saving resources. There is not much diversity. Parking must be paid for.

job_title: Software Engineer in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale provides good benefits such as health, dental, and vision. They provide a generous vacation package for long timers. You can have the opportunity to work with some brilliant faculty members.
cons: Overall Yale lacks career opportunities if you are not a faculty member. In my department there are a lot of employees who are paid very well, but do very little. They actually cause more problems for the people who have to fix them. Management in my department lacks management skills. A lot of projects I have worked on have had very little planning.

review_title: Great People and Opportunity to Learn on a Smaller Scale
job_title: Intern in New Haven, CT
pros: The overall atmosphere and people that you work with are on par with the best you could ask for. Provides the opportunity to learn about college athletics at a more modest level
cons: Begining to work in athletics can have a slow start. You must be patient and willing to start low and work your way up to where you want to be

job_title: Research Scientist in New Haven, CT
pros: Lot of funding for research. Relaxed environment. Flexible schedule. Nice coworkers and administration. Good salary for comparable positions. Great support offices to career, outreach, patents
cons: Huge ego among senior professors and scientist (some of them). Projects are started on the basis "my archenemy is doing it so we have to do it too". No vision of the big picture.

review_title: Yale is a good place for a biochemistry PhD
job_title: PhD Student, Biochemistry in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale has great faculty, good training in first and second year, moderate TA requirements, guaranteed funding for 5 years, good facilities, and talented students.
cons: The PhD program in the 2nd-4th year would benefit from more structure and advising. Many students aren't as productive in this period as they could be, and it's due to lack of guidance.

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in New Haven, CT
pros: The university is very well equipped, the core facility is good. The environment is very stimulating with great science, tons of invited speakers and opportunities for collaboration. Yale has great resources: workshops, office for carrier advice.
cons: The work pressure is horrendous and it is hard to find the proper work-life balance.  Postdocs are usually very isolated.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale University takes care of their employees regardless of their position within the university. Health care is provided, Yale has their own hospital to serve their employees, and they take your personal happiness very serious.
cons: As with most Universities, your experience at Yale University will completely depend on the position and group you join. As a postdoctoral Associate in a research lab it completely depends on the group you join, the demands set by your PI and your research whether your time spent at the University will be a positive or negative experience.

review_title: Yale has the potential to be a great place to work
job_title: Administrative in New Haven, CT
pros: interesting people to work with, good benefits.
cons: Union and Management don't get along very well.  Both sides continually try to stick it to the other, Management hiding their bad behavior and the Union never trusting anything said to them (with good reason.)

review_title: The Mission of Teaching, Learning and Research make this a Great Place to Work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: To be part of this esteemed University is a privilege.  You work with some great minds working to make the world a better place:.  Educating Future Leaders; Discovering New Advances in Science, Medicine, Social Scienes and the Humanities.
cons: With knowledge and experience of Academia, the leadership lacks the experience of running a large organization.  There is a struggle to connect with Mission and Vision of the University with the need to create an effective and efficient administration.

review_title: Great benefits, good hours, but slow beauracracy
job_title: Assistant Director of Publications in New Haven, CT
pros: Benefits package; hours are good; week off at Christmas; good time off package.
cons: It can be very slow getting through HR and the hiring process.  After a hire, some offices are obsessed with the "hierarchy" of the office structure and it can make it difficult to complete minute tasks.

job_title: Technician in New Haven, CT
pros: Stimulating work experience by associating and collaborating with intelligent and inspiring researchers.
cons:
Location is in New Haven, a city with many problems and with a dismal future.  Upper level administrators are stoic and not adaptable to changes, which results in an immense waste of time and money on renovation and planning projects.  
Any correction to policies or procedures are done mainly for show and not based on effectiveness.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: A wonderful place for research, good colleagues, state of the art infrastructure, strong research support, decent benefits, prestigious position
cons: Competitive environment, complex politics, so-so salary, heterogenous pay scales, clinics work often feels under appreciated compared to research, sink-or-swim mentality, limited advancement possibilities in this role

job_title: Instructor in New Haven, CT
pros: Excellent committed people who aspire to help those in need. Certain offices can be remarkable family-friendly, allowing to work from home via telecommuting
cons: Compared to working in industry/corporate settings, salaries tend to be lower. Salary support for researchers not provided by University. Some technology infrastructure and organizational processes seem outdated compared to other Tier 1 universities.

review_title: You will learn a lot but it will require hardwork, motivation & flexibility.
job_title: Project Manager in New Haven, CT
pros:
The benefits are *amazing*! Free health insurance for you and your entire famiy if you earn <85K; a modest amount if you earn >85K.  The retirment is awesome, too.
You are surrounded by very bright minds. There are many great opportunities to learn new skills.
cons: Their pay is not competitive, especially for the northeast U.S.  Teams are often top heavy.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: I can meet top talents here from all over the world, and working with them helps me discover my potentials to do fascinating things that I have never thought about before. There are lots of job opportunities that we can access. Yale is a great place that helps promote people to be among top  talents in the world.
cons: New Haven is not a good place to live. Not safe,  and housing here is too expensive. Not enough apartments in safe areas offered to postdocs.

review_title: not as good as I had imagined
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in New Haven, CT
pros: good name,  lot of professors,  good benefits,  nice library,  overall management is good,  convenient and a big variety of lunch options
cons: small city without airport,   not a safe haven,  nights are boring, GYM close too early on weekends and holidays.  Too much security.  health center isn't as great.

review_title: Best place to work as a student, but lots of bureaucracy
job_title: Level III Student Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: The base pay for student and grad student work is hard to rival, and makes it impossible to think about ever working for less. Payment is easy, a lot of the schools employing processees are really transparent.
cons: Filling positions here takes forever, I would have taken another job at the company but the employment process dragged on longer than I could afford to wait.

job_title: Administrative in New Haven, CT
pros: Benefits are good (but over recent years, they have started cutting benefits... so soon this may not be a pro).
cons: They could care less about loyalty and retention of employees.  Top heavy with management.  Too much like a corporation (without the high pay of a corporation).

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Great academic environment: top departments in cell biology, biophysics/biochemistry, immunology, others. I've always found other to be kind, genuine people.
cons: Postdoc salary, need I say more? Luckily career consulting services abound at every turn so you don't have to stick around if you don't want to. At the same time, though there's a surfeit of biology PhDs and postdocs, so you have to find a way to stand out.

job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros:
My experience is as PhD student:
Working with some of the most brilliant & innovative professors in the world
Lots of resources for advanced research in most fields
Great stipend and benefits guaranteed for 5 years.
Great academic network and alumni network
cons: As with other grad schools: it's very important to find an advisor you enjoy working with or enduring a long PhD program is difficult. For smaller departments, its important to find someone who is a suitable match before you apply.

review_title: A great place for scientific research, but safety is a concern in New Haven
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in New Haven, CT
pros:
Yale has a great health care system. 
It offers a well-rounded scientific community with lots resources and many possibilities for collaborative research.
Great reputation.
cons:
Not very safe at the high crime rate city of New Haven.
A little bureaucracy even in the world of science.
Very humid summer.

job_title: PhD Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Access to excellent additional funding for six guaranteed years and through other sources also for longer such as other research funds. Great relation to Professors
cons: Sadly Yale is located in New Haven, CT. One the one hand it provides a good student life but other amenities are missing for sure. Needs to continue to hire faculty in emerging fields

job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New Haven, CT
pros: Many brilliant people and plenty of money to make things happen quickly when the Deans are behind it.
cons: I came from a very pro-union household (my father was a coal miner) and appreciated the protection unions gave. They unions at Yale are out of control and give good unions a bad name. People literally do nothing and get paid great wages for it.

review_title: Wonderful Place to Work and Live
job_title: Editor in New Haven, CT
pros: Great Community, Wonderful Education- Culturally Enriching.  School of Management has a new facility, as does forestry. The new class of undergrads is very excited and friendly, so many vibrant employees and students- it's hard to go wrong attending or working at Yale.
cons: Yale is a wonderful place museums, art science. This is a cultural repository for the last 800,000 years of humanities existence. It's a little overwhelming with so many opportunities it's impossible to take advantage of them all.

review_title: Great pay for a student job! Really appreciate the opportunity to work as a student tech, would do it again.
job_title: Student Tech in New Haven, CT
pros:
-Beautiful campus
-Friendly fellow employees
-Great attentive employers who will listen to your suggestions and implement them fairly quickly. Idea turnaround/innovation is great here. 
-Everything is fairly centralized and close to each other; there isn't much travel time between locations.
-Training sessions are paid and fun!
cons:
-Sometimes high-stress workload
-Expected to fix too many problems with too little resources (too little manpower).
-Sometimes understaffed
-Not much room to climb up (expected, though).

review_title: Pay is good, while it lasts.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros: Compared to average teaching assistant positions at graduate school, the pay and benefits are very good.
cons: University takes little consideration of individual circumstances and needs. Recent layoffs across the university means higher level managers have no idea what is going on at the department level.

review_title: Depends on the position and manager
job_title: Practice Manager in New Haven, CT
pros: The benefits are incredible, as well as the prestige of the institution.  There are certainly brilliant people here.
cons: There is an "old" Yale mentality in some longtime staff and managers.  Very unpleasant people to deal with.   There is a culture shift occurring as the poor behavior is tolerated less and less.

review_title: Overall, a great place to do a PhD
job_title: Graduate Student
pros: Very collegial (as one might expect), good work/life balance as far as grad schools go, and very good support from administration ranging from significantly above average stipends to career services and student life activities.
cons: As with most prominent academic institutions, many big egos and dead weight, sometimes mediocre teaching at the grad level. Also, very little industry collaboration vs other schools (i.e. Stanford, MIT, etc).

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros:
It is the well know university. Easy to get the fund from the government or the companies. 
Good research resources to prompt the research work
cons:
Slightly dangerous area to work until late night. 
No space to park in the day time or very expensive parking fee even if have to park in the far parking lot.

job_title: Master's Aide in New Haven, CT
pros: Lots of freedom to do your work when the office isn't busy, which is almost always. Also, first crack at sign-ups!
cons: Not a lot of direction at the start, they really do just toss you in. It can be hard to know even what to ask at first.

job_title: Banquet Server in New Haven, CT
pros: Most of the people here are friendly and want you to succeed.  The banquet servers work as a team and help each other as much as possible.
cons: Upper level management seems unfriendly at times and can come off as extremely rude when providing instruction.  Sometimes feels more commanding than instructional.

review_title: Fun place to work that can stagnate
job_title: Lecturer in New Haven, CT
pros: Wonderful atmosphere, excellent benefits, appealing culture and environment as well as many services to take advantage of. Smart people, without a strong emphasis on profit.
cons: Large bureaucracy at times, which can be slow to act. Authority from the top can seem distant or aimless. Lower salary than private sector.

job_title: C&T in New Haven, CT
pros: Great company with Excellent Benefits!!  Plenty of time off, and (depending on where you work & who you work for), offers flexibility that allow you to not feel guilty about handling personal affairs / attend appointments when needed.
cons: Can have long days at times!!

job_title: Post Doctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Some of the greatest minds in the work help to train you and make sure your research is top notch.  Additionally the environment is friendly and inclusive.
cons: Like all academic post doc positions, the salary is low.  Additionally sometimes there are issues with politics.  I think this is not specific to Yale, but probably academia in general.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: The teaching experience is not too onerous. Class sizes are relatively small. As a PhD candidate, your pay will not be much, but much higher than some other institutions.
cons: The location is desolate and dangerous. You would have a better quality of life if you lived in a big city. The program is a little disorganised, but that varies from department to department.

job_title: IT Support Specialist in New Haven, CT
pros: Good work life balance, excellent overall benefits package (health care coverage, tuition reimbursement, paid time off, etc.).  The work/office culture largely depends on the specific department you work in.
cons: Due to tradition and especially the sheer size of the university, the wheels of change (i.e. positive improvements) at Yale can move very slowly.  This can be quite frustrating at times.

review_title: great if your boss care about your research
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Work-life balance is decent, salary is OK for postdocs, a lot of funding that means you can buy anything you need for your research.
cons: Professors with too much funding and big ego.  No team work. Too many projects in which the principal investigator knows little or nothing about. The lab is run as a company.

job_title: in New Haven, CT
