pros: Lots of work to do and you learn SAS skills by doing those work. In the end you will be familiar with several procedure in SAS.
cons: The job is more repetitive than you might think. You did not get to know the project well and sometimes it had not enough advice from your supervisor. The pay is also petty.

review_title: Exciting and stimulating research environment, with a few drawbacks
job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Generous pay as a pre-doctoral research assistant, and plenty of opportunities to go to guest lectures, audit courses, prep for exams (e.g., GRE), etc. Good perks like cheap gym access, bus around town, and Yale discounts in town.
cons: Not that much oversight, and little coordination between researchers and RAs in different teams/departments.

review_title: Great place to be a student and to live for a few years.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale has a lot of resources for students, and great professors, labs, and other people. It is a very unique place in all that it offers and really allows students the opportunity to grow and learn a lot about themselves and the world.
cons: Not a great place for engineering or science students to gain lots of hands-on experience of prepare for careers working with hands-on things.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Nice colleagues, smart students. Yale is an amazing university. You will find a lot of good and smart people to interact.  New Haven is great!
cons: I don't really have any complains. Yale is an amazing university. You will find a lot of good and smart people to interact. New Haven is great!

job_title: Programmer Analyst in New Haven, CT
pros: The benefits and the all the activities you are able to expierence.  There are many fringe benefites als o pension and great people.
cons: Some communication between senior staff about their ideas and goals to their staff.  Pace is hard to get use to.  Also the functional side want certain things done but they are unwilling or yunable to test.

job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: great co-workers, close to New York and Boston. Other than crime, the city itself is actually nice. Yale is trying hard to revitalize the area, but that may take a long time.
cons:
high crime rate in the city

horrible management at some departments, they need to change with the times and get rid of the dinosaurs holding progress back

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Peer tutoring is the best. You get to help out tons of people. It helps you refine your knowledge.
cons: Sometimes it can be very busy and tiring. Sometimes jobs are understaffed as there are too many people to help in that amount of time.

job_title: Data Scientist in Columbus, OH
pros: My coworkers are inspiring and seek excellence in their specialties.  I work as a data scientist in an interdisciplinary team studying cancer.
cons: My work is done over the Internet.  I only have face-to-face contact with my coworkers about twice a year.  My appointment is part time.  .

job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Behind the scene access to the creation of world-class courses. Active engagement with bright student body. A chance to re-learn topics.
cons: Tasks can at times be mundane. Teaching takes time away form research, which is really the graduate student's focus. Students can sometimes quibble over grades.

job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Very prestigious university. Lots of academic resources and lots of career options after graduation. Students are treated well. A good choice and you'll never regret it.
cons: The town is not as safe as one would like. Never walk out alone at night. Better live in one of the several relatively safe neighborhoods.

review_title: Research Assistant in Psychiatry Department, enjoyed my time there
job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Lots of interesting work opportunities. Opportunities for attending interesting talks. Nice people in my experience. Good benefits package once you get hired and competitive wages. A great place to start a career or gain experience.
cons: It might take some time to get hired. You might find after a while in the same job that you have to get more education or training or go elsewhere if you want to advance.

review_title: Overall a stimulating environment.  Can be a little challenging when there is a budget shortfall.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Benefits!!  Medical and paid time off can't be rivaled. Work hours are equally liberal.  The new Haven area is fantastic location to work and play.  Tons of social activities.
cons: Stagnation.  Hard to advance without hopping around.  Well funded departments are able to remain lightweight and flexible while core services lumber with many vestigial services.

job_title: Social Media Intern in New Haven, CT
pros: The position as a social media intern at the Yale office of communications offers flexible hours which is great for a student worker. Additionally, there's a lot of opportunities to lead interesting and diverse projects with a cool team.
cons: The job offers limited growth opportunity by the very fact that it is geared towards student workers. However, you have quite some ownership over your work which is highly transferable to jobs in communications and marketing.

review_title: A great employer, but not actually as competitive as they'd like you to believe.
job_title: Program Manager in New Haven, CT
pros:
"Golden shackles"
Excellent benefits, nice town, very stable. 
Pay is ok, but not great. Claims to be "market rate" but that seems only quasi consistent.
cons: Overall, not very adaptable to change. Budget fluctuations are unpredictable and seemingly arbitrary. HR puts on a good show about development and opportunities for growth but it ends up lacking in substance. Most mid-upper level hires come from outside the university.

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale has excellent environment for research.  Research teams are very good.  International standard of work and it  is widely collaborated with other universities and institues around the world!
cons: New Haven is not a big city and the security condition needs to improve.   The transportation is not convenient as the metropolitans.  Especially when you travel for meeting and conference to some  states or countries, which are far away.

job_title: Office Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Great benefits for earlier hires, nice work environment, beautiful campus, high salaries. The co-workers were also great, but it, of course, varies by department.
cons: The benefits were reduced for new hires in the last few years (although still good). I heard complaints about parking although I never ran into this problem since I lived within walking distance to my work. Few advancement opportunities for those at the top of the clerical and technical category.

job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Ample opportunities to develop your skills for both the academic and non-academic job markets. Postdoctoral office tries it's best to give career guidance for postdocs.
cons: If your PI does not believe in a non-academic career pathway, he/she will be a huge road block to get yourself prepared for your career choices.

job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New Haven, CT
pros: Great facilities, famous scientists, beautiful campus, great benefits.
cons: Low salaries, poor opportunities for advancement/tenure, some individuals with harsh and abusive management practices and little recourse available, not very much support in career advancement outside of academia.  Some professors no not care about your discoveries; some discoveries and ideas are stolen and you are not credited.

review_title: Student pay is great, hours are flexible
job_title: Student Tech in New Haven, CT
pros: Really high student minimum wage, administrators/bosses are very sympathetic to student responsibilities and allow for flexible scheduling
cons: Sometimes the responsibilities given to you at these student minimum wage jobs are very limited - not a whole lot of learning involved/irregular trainings

job_title: Yale Finance Analyst in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale University has great people and provides an environment for growth and success. I think that overall people enjoy working here.
cons: Not always the most rigorous or interesting work -- can get a bit monotonous. Also need to find a way to diversify the work environment as well.

job_title: Library Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: As a Library Student Assistant I was able to work flexibly while maintaining a rigorous class schedule.
cons: The pay was rather low, but since I was a student worker I understand why. Yet they should have a bigger pay scale for students too.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: The department is awkwardly trying to position itself in a framework of social practice, when in reality nobody cares about political and social issues, it is all about formalism and favoritism.
cons: Extremely competitive and unsupportive environment, especially if you don't fit into their idea of you

review_title: The regulatory department is a complete nightmare! Stay away!!!
job_title: Regulatory Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: You learn a lot, very low cost insurance. Holiday time off.
cons: Low pay, not enough people,over worked, disorganized, no support from anyone. Stop giving preference to the clinic side and give more support to the regulatory department. The doctors don’t appreciate your worth. You are a senior project manager not an assistant. The job title is false. The regulatory department needs serious revamping and organization. The amount of work with minimal pay is extremely low compared to pharmaceutical industries. The expectations in the department are extremely high.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale is a good place to work overall with a good benefit package for people who have been there for a long time.
cons: some policies are a joke especially when it comes to IT.  Often new systems are instituted that are not well designed

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: I worked with great people and really learned a lot. It was an excellent experience overall, and I would do it all over again.
cons: There weren't any real downsides that I can think of, but this box has a twenty word minimum so I have to put something.

job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: You get income and valuable research experience working as a RA in a top lab. Pay is good relative to other universities and mentorship is excellent.
cons: Working as an RA is time consuming and difficult, but that's really what you want - to push yourself if you want to go into academia.

job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale is a good place to earn your doctorate from in bio-sciences because of the diverse research options, great student stipend and benefits, and collaborative research environment. Depending on the people you choose to study under, there is the opportunity for flexible working hours.
cons: Gettting your doctorate from Yale can be challenging due to the high publication expectations and therefore constant pressure to succeed. This translates into long working hours.

review_title: Couldn't find a better place to work!
job_title: Student Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: High student minimum wage, nice and friendly people. Never experienced any difficulties during the two years I was employed. Would recommend to anyone!
cons: Kind of a pain to get to and from work - the shuttles are not always the most reliable, but they do a decent job. New Haven gets quite cold in the winter, so be prepared for that.

job_title: Student Tech in New Haven, CT
pros: This was a great job, I was very satisfied with my work and the team.  Great compensation, gained valuable customer service experience and loved helping students who were technologically challenged.
cons: This was a great job, I was very satisfied with my work and the team.  Great compensation, gained valuable customer service experience and loved helping students who were technologically challenged.  There were no real cons.

review_title: Bittersweet experience, it is not always good or great in everything here even it is one of the most prestigious edu.
job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros:
Great exposure to various  social activities and networking
Been surrounded by hardworking and smart minds
Lots of collaborations and resources.
cons: Getting funding and competition is really tough, especially for junior research faculties. Correspondingly, the stress is huge for both PI and postdocs. Choosing the right person to work is way more important than others.

review_title: I've been working for Yale University for over twenty years.
job_title: Lab Tech in New Haven, CT
pros: I've receive promotions.  Benefits are superb.  The people are awesome, because you are interacting with people from all around the world.
cons: The challenges would be the injuries that occurred at Yale, which could have been prevented, which cause me to have to leave my last position.   These injuries occurred because of the errors of others.

job_title: Student Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: There are a lot of opportunities and funding for undergraduate research in all fields, including physical science, natural science, and social science.
cons: There are very few cons. Again, there are a lot of opportunities and funding for undergraduate research in all fields, including physical science, natural science, and social science.

review_title: Yale does not deserve the prestige it advertises
job_title: Research Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Depending on who your boss is there is a good amount of flexibility in your schedule. Decent benefits
cons: You will never appreciated for experience or length of service. I've been paid less than people who just started with no experience. M&Ps are not encouraged to make this a life long career

job_title: Senior Network Engineer in New Haven, CT
pros: Working with some of the most talented people in IT makes you feel inspired to learn more. Everyone is very passionate about what they do. There is a contagious thirst to learn more each day.
cons: Due to the culture of the environment, change is not quick. Many innovations fall to the side due to a lack of management interest or supports. It is a historical environment that wants to stay historical.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale has demonstrated her scientific excellence. I am please to be a member. Smart people are everywhere. It is very good in terms of personal growth.
cons: There is very competitive research environment. You have to work off hours. Salary is way too low. People get promoted slow.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Wonderful people and a great opportunity to gain new skills.  I had the chance to take on new leadership roles.  Also, being paid by the hour, stellar.
cons: Irregular hour and lots of pressure during the busy season.

review_title: Really great community, but job can be a little boring
job_title: Phone Program Caller in New Haven, CT
pros:
-Watch Netflix on large TV while you make calls
-Occasionally talk to really interesting alums
-You can get closer to your co-workers that you might expect given the nature of the job
-Incentives if you do a good job (more money!)
-Pick your own hours (sort of): You don't have to go to the same calling sessions every week.
cons:
-Sometimes can be boring
-Supervisor sometimes goes on long spiels

job_title: Manager
pros: Good students, good food, food atmosphere, not that dangerous when you do not go out into the city, great benefits, great co-workers, great city overall.
cons: Only have one complaint and that's how they need to provide us with more working hours. at other universities, some stores are open longer.

review_title: OK but want to move on
job_title: Research Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale has a great reputation; people are smart and friendly, although not always helpful; a lot of choices to do things you are interested
cons: New Haven is not a safe place to live; life-style is generally boring; go to New York less often then I thought

job_title: Researcher in Yale, SD
pros: People at Yale are very nice, I like the friendly air and freedom here. The academic atmosphere is also fascinating.
cons: The weather is cold for a long period of time, and New Haven is a small city though, it is not suitable for people who need frequent shopping.

job_title: Lead Financial Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Excellent pay and benefits. Opportunities for advancement and lateral moves. Ongoing training classes are usually optional and are great. I worked at the Law School for 12 years and it was the job of a lifetime for me.
cons: Parking is a little difficult, but there are trains and shuttles. Best if you are healthy enough to be able to walk among the Yale buildings and surrounding shops.

job_title: Associate Professor in New Haven, CT
pros:
-World-class research environment with state-of-the-art facilities
-broad range of expertise across many different departments
-University with International reputation
-Reasonable teaching load
cons:
-Lack of mentoring structure for junior faculty
-many senior faculty members are backward-looking
-opaque promotion mechanisms
-over 8 years, got no raise for several years and only 1-2% raise in all but one of the other years, when the raise was ~5%.

review_title: Loved the work, the pay was terrible
job_title: Clinical Social Worker in New Haven, CT
pros:
The benefits were great, matching funds for retirement fund, free entry into all Yale buildings, museums, libraries etc. 
It was very intellectually stimulating and challenging
cons: The pay was terrible, as a woman I was treated differently than men and my salary showed it. You must pay for parking at approx $80/mo.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Great scientific environment. Talks, seminars, knowledgeable colleagues. Labs are led by independent PIs, as such work environments vary greatly
cons: High paced environment, which is not necessarily a negative. It is a great place for people who want to emerge themselves in science.

job_title: Systems Programmer II in New Haven, CT
pros: Great benefits and reasonable work hours can make Yale a good place for employees with children.
cons: Yale is a difficult place for younger employees to excel and advance, since pay and promotions are tied more strongly to years of service than to performance.  Pay overall lags behind private-sector jobs, and the university often takes a very long time to implement strategy changes.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale has great research facilities and encourages inter-departmental research. Some of the most creative minds work at Yale University.
cons: Probably the biggest con of Yale University is its location in New Haven. Even though the crime rate is decreasing every year it is not the typical New England small town.

job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Great work environment, exciting campus life, and wonderful student body.  Beautiful campus with lots of oppurtunites for growth and change.
cons: Cold winters and short summers with rain and clouds.  Business is slow during summer months when students leave the campus.

review_title: The Poison Ivy League: Yale University
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros: Access to a number of facilities and resources that are cutting edge, also a lot of financial and administrative resources.
cons: Relationships can be brisk with professors and others in managing, power positions. Lots of pressure to produce in a little time. Some areas of the university are not the most collegial, when it comes to working together.

job_title: Event Coordinator in New Haven, CT
pros:
Typically Relaxed atmosphere
Work with students regularly
Free food at kosher dinning hall
Payment system works well
Understanding management
cons:
Little room for upward mobility; you do your one job and stick with it
Turnover has happened recently where many long-term employees lost their jobs
Keep in mind this is for the Hillel on campus ONLY, not the university itself.

review_title: You must take the good with the bad
job_title: Associate Professor in New Haven, CT
pros: Excellent colleagues across many disciplines.  Few students, but they are generally excellent. Extremely rich endowment allows Yale to do things that other school could only dream of.  Gorgeous campus.
cons: High pressure, opaque tenure system.  Still downplaying and sweeping their past misogyny and racism under the rug.  Risk-averse, highly bureaucratic, money grubbing culture.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros: There are many high profile professors, and, of course, Yale has an immediate name recognition associated with it. Just make sure to pick your lab and mentor wisely.
cons: Postdocs aren't considered employees and receive benefits that are terrible in comparison to real employees (students get much better healthcare benefits too).

review_title: Good place to work, not for too long.
job_title: Research Assistant I in New Haven, CT
pros: Work with brilliant people on interesting projects. There are lots of opportunities to learn if you seek them out. Great place to network.
cons: Rigid structure makes it impossible to move up the ladder or do anything beyond what you were hired to do. It's good to be there for a while, but must leave in order to develop career any further.

job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros:
-Great Environment 
-Fair pay
-Contact with some of the smartest people in the world
-Excellent learning environment especially prior to undertaking a PhD
cons: There are none that I can think of. The university definitely treats its workers with great care and offers fair compensation. Its also great to be in an environment where you are constantly learning from others and from your work

job_title: Bio Statistician in New Haven, CT
pros:
+ One of the best places I've ever worked.
+ I always felt empowered.
+ A lot of smart people working hard to do good things.
+ Very generous benefits.
+ Comfortable working environment and culture.
+ Very responsive management and HR Department.
cons:
+ As with most academic/nonprofit institutions, salaries are lower than in industry.
+ I understand that responsiveness of management depends on each department.

job_title: Assistant Director in New Haven, CT
pros: Good pay. Great benefits. Great overall environment.
cons: Diversity is a by-word but not really practiced. Very difficult for the (mostly female) Clerical & Technical staff to break into Managerial & Professional ranks. Even more difficult for the (mostly minority) Facilities staff to get promoted. Also, difficult to get good feedback from managers.

review_title: Great place to work, less room to grow
job_title: DEPARTMENT of PSYCHIATRY in New Haven, CT
pros:
Flexible work schedule
Great health benefits
Great benefits overall
Intellectual work environment with progressive thinkers
cons:
Lower salary than other institutions. 
Can't really move up unless you get another degree
Difficult to navigate job searches when there are so many different departments and projects going on at the same time

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros: Lots of opportunity for learning new technologies and methods. Great workshops to learn computer based analysis and bioinformatics.
cons: This place is filled with unimpressive employees, postdocs and technicians. I expected people with a higher level of knowledge.    Since there isn't much collaboration between equipment, the labs are pretty low on equipment.  The core facilities tend to be great though.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: It's Yale. Overall, it's a very bright and engaging community.
cons: If you are not tenure-track, the pay is very low and any complaints regarding sexual/racial discrimination are largely dismissed. There are no jobs in academia, and universities like Yale are continuing to admit grad students on the false premise that their degree will lead to a job in academia.

review_title: One of the good places to learn, work and grow intellectually.  The University provides excellent network to connect.
job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Best minds in the world are your peers. You get to work on the important projects which will give you high impact results.
cons: The city of new Haven is not the best place to live in but a great place to have fun.

job_title: ITS in New Haven, CT
pros:
Amazing benefits package and competitive salaries.
Tons of paid time off per year, this includes more than four weeks of vacation/personal time, as well as holidays, recesses, and sick time.
cons:
Limited opportunities for promotions or job growth.
People tend to remain here for a long time, limiting opportunities to move up the ladder.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: There are many positives: there is a lot of opportunity for growth, a real collaborative culture, decent pay, and all of the perks of being part of a university community
cons: None that I can think of. If you're working on the support side of things, staff/students can be a little over-the-top, though this is to be expected wherever.

job_title: Research Assistant I in New Haven, CT
pros: Stability, union, health care, 403b, 2 weeks paid vacation each year, 12 sick days, paid between Christmas and new years. They are decently flexible with time. It will always look great on your resume to be hired by Yale.
cons: Job growth difficult. There are not that many opportunities to get a job in Yale that has more pay, responsibility, or degree of meaningful input.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Pros
Kind staff, health insurance, employee comp nights at any four seasons, free lunches, open-door policy all the way up to top management
cons: The things that bothered me the most were how short lunch breaks are (approx. 30 minutes - including how long it takes to get there and back), and the inconsistency of schedules

review_title: Not the perfect oasis it seems from outside, but working here will have long-term benefits for you.
job_title: Video Producer in New Haven, CT
pros:
1) Being part of an internationally renowned organization.
2) Beautiful campus.
3) Great health benefits
cons:
1) Low pay.
2) Little interaction with people outside your area because the university is so siloed.
3) Health benefits monthly contribution continues climbing each year.
4) New Haven

job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Very stimulating environment. Lots of smart people around. Quite laid back. Although depends on the advisor. So choose your boss carefully.
cons: Lots of red-tape-ism. Things are still quite retro. Things can be quite slow at times so you have yo be patient.

review_title: Yale has some of the best paid and happiest employers on a university campus.
job_title: Office Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Salary is higher than in most higher education institutions and management is happy and well paid. New Haven isn't the most beautiful city but campus is gorgeous and safe.
cons: New Haven is not the liveliest city for a young person. NYC is only a train ride away but nightlife is scarce.

job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros:
Pushing the edge of science. Top tier learning environment. 
Great benefits free* health care (*added to your taxes).
cons:
Campus spread out within the city. Lots of walking to go from one place to another or have to ride the bus. 

Some postdocs are forced to attend summer series. Most only know about it a month in advance. So, don't make plans.

review_title: Not without its own flaws, but Yale is a terrific employer
job_title: Project Coordinator in New Haven, CT
pros: I had tried for years to get a job at Yale University and when I finally got an offer, I was overjoyed. I haven't been disappointed. It's not without its flaws, but I'm thrilled to be working for the university.
cons: Honestly, nothing yet. I've really enjoyed it.

review_title: Awesome First Job Out of College
job_title: Admissions Officer in New Haven, CT
pros: A surprising degree of independence.
cons: Heartbreaking to deny so many awesome applicants. Unlike peers schools, such as Columbia or Penn, there's no real opportunity at Yale to earn a masters degree while working full-time at Yale Undergraduate Admissions - which is REALLY too bad as that would be a primary benefit given the modest salaries for new, young hires.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Great pay and interesting work. The university makes it easy to find jobs that are available to the community and facilitates the application process.
cons: None that I can think of. Jobs at the university are near where students live and are high paying (or at least enough so given the student contribution) compared to their equivalents outside the university.

job_title: Senior IT Analyst in New Haven, CT
pros: Great benefits and vacation time.  Flexible work schedule.  When the economy tanked in 2008 many benefits were slashed including PDO for new employees.
cons: Management is spread too thin.  The IT support structure was based on departments instead of locations.  So if you covered one department in particular you could be running all over town.

job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Being a PhD student at Yale could open up various future pathways for you, no matter which program you are in, it's not hard to built connection with people from different background, and most of them are at elite level.
cons: Advisors might lean to cultivate their students into a future faculty, atmosphere here is more old-school if compared with MIT and Stanford.

job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Very stimulating environment. A good place to pick up hard skills and network (excellent alumni database). Good healthcare facilities excellent.
cons: Not the best social environment, I guess typical of the ivy league environment. New Haven is a crime ridden city.

job_title: Student Worker in New Haven, CT
pros: As an undergraduate on work-study, there will be a job for you. It is up to you to explore your options but you shouldn't be left in the cold. The pay is high for a student so it helps you earn a livable amount while not sacrificing your academics.
cons: These are student jobs, so a lot of them can be tedious/monotonous.

review_title: I am working as a research assistant in the Electrical Engineering Department at Yale.
job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale is a world renowned academic institution. Graduating from here provides an opportunity to work in good companies.
cons: New Haven is not a very good place for living. It's not very safe in the night.

job_title: PhD Candidate in New Haven, CT
pros: Great resources and smart people create an awesome environment to foster learning!
cons: Depending on department pressure on graduate students might be very high, but I guess that's the case at any university.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale University was a great organization to work for. Everyone is very mission driven. There was a lot of work-life balance, and the benefits were amazing!
cons: There were a lot of politics. There was not a lot of upward mobility, I had to hope someone would leave or retire in order to be advanced.

job_title: EHS in New Haven, CT
pros: The benefits and the ability to network are the greatest aspects of working at the University. The wide range of job opportunities are also a positive.
cons: The main challenge I found in working in the support field was the language barrier. Because the University is diverse, there are so many different languages.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Bright, engaged students. A pleasure to teach tutorials.
cons: Inability to give some students the grades they deserve (i.e. C's, D's and F's) because of concerns related to parental involvement.

review_title: I really enjoyed going to the university.
job_title: Career Advisor in New Haven, CT
pros: i enjoyed going to Yale because of the professors and the advisors were very helpful in guding my career to meet my goals.
cons: I don't have any cons to say about Yale University. Maybe they could lower tuition for us.

job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Pay was fair for the work, and the work itself was very interesting. Flexibility was very high, and easy to ask for.
cons: Leadership was weak university wide for all levels. Academic teaching mission was a distant second or third to other objectives.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: A healthy sense of accomplishment and willingness to listen to all sides of the story.
cons: Somewhat inflated sense of importance about the life and times of employees and students.

job_title: Research Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Some of the best minds in the world are here, and are often quite accessible.  Tons of opportunity to learn new things and work with talented people.
cons: If you aren't a faculty member there's a huge limit to what you are given and what you can accomplish.

job_title: Student Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: It's a good work environment, my bosses are friendly and understanding. I feel very much a part of this community.
cons: New Haven is no New York City. The winter here is miserable; the summer is muggy and super hot. But Yale is good to its students as far as jobs go, our minimum wage is super high.

job_title: Student Tech in New Haven, CT
pros:
Good work-life balance
Leads really care about you
Get to do really interesting work, and learn as you go!
cons: It can be hard to balance a full schedule with work, and it can be tough if you're not put on a team which you like (I am on a team that I do like)

job_title: PhD Student in New Haven, CT
pros:
excellent benefits and guaranteed maternity (and paternity!) leave for PhD students who want to start a family
very little hassle and bureaucracy out of the graduate school
very high compensation relative to cost of living
excellent networking opportunities and career services initiatives
cons:
new haven is terrible
work life balance is highly dependent on which research group you wind up with

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros:
Great place for a postdoc. However ask the good questions during your interview, to be sure to work with a great PI (not always the case!)
Health insurance is awesome!
cons: Everything depend on your PI/lab: long work hours, old equipment (but still in a good shape to do experiments!), less collaboration than you would think about it.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Great learning opportunity. The faculty is second to none. Offers the experience to get real teaching experience and focus on research.
cons: The university does not offer proper compensation to teaching assistants or adjuncts. Of course this is part of a much broader problem in the academic landscape.

review_title: Great institution to conduct research at as a grad student
job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: excellent research resources (labs, library access, excellent faculty and students). Nice, small city oriented around the university. Great access to other metro areas in Northeast- Boston, NYC...etc.
cons: Small city-setting may not appeal to people used to large metropolitan cities. Prestige and pedigree are highly (over??) valued among faculty and students.

review_title: It is a very laid back atmosphere. A lot of departments have cool research projects.
job_title: Research Assistant I in New Haven, CT
pros: Gain experience and knowledge about different research going on.
cons: Don't get caught up in gossip. Some times you do more duties than what your job entails. Just do it and gain the experience and continue to move up.

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The position offered incredible learning opportunities at an institution rich in history  There were benefits to working in a small team with the resources of a large organization that offered lots of opportunities for internal advancement..
cons: There was a significant amount of focus on process and some of the bureaucracy that comes from working for a large university

job_title: Ph D Student In Mechanical Engineering in New Haven, CT
pros:
1, Nice advisors (in personality and research);
2, A lot of opportunities and benifits
cons:
1, The Engineering departments are small;
2, Kind of easy to survive. Self-motivation is strongly needed. I would prefer a place with more intense competition like Tsinghua University, where I got my B.Eng. Degree.

job_title: Music Library Online Reserves Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros:
- flexible hours
- easy to learn the job
- nice boss
- peaceful work environment
- immediate access to music library resources
- fair pay
cons:
- monotonous work
- a bit out-of-date technology
- not much room for job advancement
- mostly individual work, which can become lonely
- difficult to get other work done (i.e. studying) at the same time

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Flexible, good work/life balance, 37.5 hour work week, good health options offered, decent salary.
cons: Salary lower than market, high cost charged by Yale to park your car, limited ability to work remotely,  high contribution charged toward health insurance monthly. Less urgency and commitment, everything is manual. Feels like you've gone back in time 10-15 years.

review_title: A good job while in college
job_title: Student LIbrarian in New Haven, CT
pros:
- way to learn the LC system
- can pick up hours during breaks
- Bass is better than SML
cons:
- Shelving can get boring
- besides learning the LC system, it isn't a job that stimulates you intellectually

review_title: just a university, lets not get hyper happy
job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New Haven, CT
pros: Good benefits for faculty, scientists with solid expertise. Not far from New York, or Boston if you need to get away.
cons: More arrogance than at other places, New Haven is a terrible city with a bad school system. Comparing to other places, salaries are rather low. Opportunities to collaborate - low.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros: I really enjoy being a postdoc here. I feel that there's a lot of support for us.
cons: New Haven is a terrible place to live. The cost of living makes even the relatively better postdoc stipend inadequate. The city is dangerous and this makes it difficult to enjoy any sort of outside life.

review_title: Graduate student employment at Yale University
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Vibrant and diverse campus environment, outstanding research environment, good student health plan and campus transportation system, generous stipend for the New Haven cost of living
cons: Research environment can be competitive, work-life balance is somewhat difficult to maintain given the highly demanding culture, surrounding city (New Haven, CT) is dangerous in many parts

review_title: Great benefits overall great place to work. Culture greatly varies by department.
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Great benefits, access to training, resources, work-life balance and great affinity groups. Lots of opportunities for advancement. Intellectually challenging.
cons: Union benefits are now significantly better than management, which disincentivizes growth at some point.

job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale research facility/ Yale health plan and Yale library/ Yale gym/ Yale campus/ Yale ISPY/ Yale shuttle/ Yale life/ Yale courses/
cons: Salary is very low/ New Haven is a very small place/ New Haven is very cold area in the winter/

job_title: Teaching Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros: Grad student stipend here is higher than most other places in the country and includes a very generous health insurance package that covers your entire family at no extra cost.
cons: The local area leaves something to be desired, but the resources of the university more than make up for the cons of the area.

review_title: Great place to start a career, but job market is terrible
job_title: PhD Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Fantastic benefits for graduate students especially those with children
cons: The work is very demanding, but worth it. There is little diversity in intellectual thought or tolerance for people with differing views.

review_title: Abundant knowledge acquired through doing research
job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: While being a student at Yale, it is very helpful for students to work for professors as research assistant to learn knowledge at the same time get paid.
cons: It never extends to long-term employment for international students - and academic research is always different from research done in the industries.

review_title: Yale is a decent place to work
job_title: Communications in New Haven, CT
pros: Smart people, pretty city, decent work life balance, good benefits especially if you have kids in college
cons: Some people have been there for years and are out of fresh ideas, it takes a long to get things done

job_title: Research Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Excellent benefits with a free Yale Health Plan and generous contributions to a 401K plan.  Faculty are dedicated and knowledgable.
cons: Parking is tight and you will probably have to pay around $100 per month to park.  There are some security issues with the occasional mugging in the area.

review_title: A great employer for people with families
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: The benefits were really good. There was also fantastic job security.
cons: The School of Medicine is a terrible place to work. The work climate on central campus is much more pleasant. Huge difference from one side of campus to the other.

job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Job security for full time positions here are excellent like other higher learning institutions. Benefits are also great like the provided health insurance through Yale health.
cons: Traveling to and from main airports to New Haven is not the most convenient as Hartford is an hour away and New York is also two hours away.

review_title: One of the best graduate stipends anywhere.
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Great community in a charming town. I really enjoy living in New Haven. Yale is a phenomenal place to live and learn.
cons: I do not like living in New England. I want to live somewhere warm so I want to move to Florida.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: It's great to work with Yale. The environment is very intellectually challenging and there are many opportunities offered.
cons: New Haven as a city is not as exciting. You feel unsafe most of the time, but Yale does a lot of things in response such as door to door services, 24/7 shuttle, and more.

review_title: Great place to work, student employee
job_title: Teaching Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros:
Yale pays its student workers far above the minimum wage. 
There are some truly interesting jobs available. 
My jobs were a great part of my education.
cons: Jobs vary, and some can be boring (shelving books). I got to to translation, TAing, and counseling, which was a lot of fun.

review_title: Simple work, but if you work hard you stand out.
job_title: Banquet Server in New Haven, CT
pros: Great pay, easy work. Something different every day. Once you get the hang of it you can work without constant supervision.
cons: A lot of the staff is lazy, and not everyone pulls their weight, and there really isn't much management can do about it.

job_title: Postgraduate Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Very good place for learning and development. Collaborative environment and great opportunities to explore ideas and do research.
cons: No opportunities to grow and university policies are more important than working environment circumstances.

job_title: DinigMangr in New Haven, CT
pros: Great Salary , Benefits and Positive Growth
cons: Lack of consistency with new concepts and Innovation - Constantly changes paths of ideas without completion which causes many disruptions.

review_title: Snapshot of life as an M&P
job_title: M&P in New Haven, CT
pros: Benefits, work-life balance, access to great events, gorgeous campus
cons: Union environment has impacted the security and salaries of management positions., high cost of parking in the city, trend to get rid of long term employees and replace with lower cost college grads

job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: they offer free shuttle line and concert. The benefit is good. Every employee has about 4 weeks vacation. The salaries are comparable to other private universities.
cons: - the city New Haven itself was not very safe, the school sent out notification of safety incidents via email.

review_title: Great Benefits, but a lot of BS in Research
job_title: Research Associate I in New Haven, CT
pros:
-A lot of time off
-Great Resources
-Good Resume Builder
cons:
-Research Politics
-Research Depts expect overtime everyday all the time
-PIs are negative and will throw their associates/assistants under a bus to protect themselves

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: excellent benefits, healthcare and retirement are very hard to beat
cons: Pay is lower than industry.  In general they are behind the times, people have lots of ideas but most things never get accomplished because there are too many people involved

job_title: Curator in New Haven, CT
pros: Great depth of resources and financial support for research.
cons: Mismanagement and micromanagement of staff. Highly educated and extremely skilled staff are not trusted for their expertise.

job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale is one of the most renowned universities of the United States and the world. Yale is both a small college and a large research university.
cons: Since Yale is such a big university there is a quite competitive environment and the chances of finding a long term-permanent job are small.

review_title: Yale Part Time Research Assistant - Student
job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: A great place to work with many friendly people.  Working with the Internal Medicine department you learn a great deal.
cons: There were few cons, however the fluctuation in the work could sometimes be difficult in scheduling your time.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: It is a good place to go and do nice research work there. The ambient of discussion is quite open and there are many great seminar every week.
cons: Yale University supplies very good training and teaching experience to the students and postdoctors. The coverage of Yale health plan is really wonderful.

review_title: Working with prof while arranging some conference materials for him. Work was easy to do but sometimes overwhelmed me.
job_title: Research Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Amazing networking and opportunities to get involve in different projects
cons: Sometimes feel overwhelmed by work and studies

job_title: Archivist Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: My supervisor was kind and patient during training. He was very generous when it came to time off, and provided an excellent environment to work in.
cons: The tasks could be tedious, but I was aware of that from the beginning.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Good Health Care Plan; Good Staff & Student Service; Good oppotunities for auditing Humanity and history courses.
cons: Salary for postdoc is not good, just the lowest level. The security is much more better than before, but sitll can be improved, maybe this is the problem of the city.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant II in New Haven, CT
pros: A rich and vibrant culture with a history stretching back 300 years. A wide variety of career opportunities in virtually every field. Great cultural opportunities.
cons: Slow moving, bureaucratic. Division between staff and faculty.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Great resources for research; fantastic student peers; prestigious and intelligent faculty
cons: New Haven can be a difficult place to live. Faculty are not incentivized to be good mentors to graduate students. There is a diffuse graduate student community.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Great health insurance; Yale Homebuyer's Program; many free professional development opportunities; prestige associated with Yale is good for your resume.
cons: Experience working here can vary enormously across schools and functional units. Some are very forward thinking and entrepreneurial and some are very stagnant.

job_title: Director in New Haven, CT
pros: Yale has amazing benefits and is very family friendly. I work a flexible schedule so that I can pick my kids up from school. Generous 403b match!
cons: Many employees have been at Yale for a very long time, which can mean that they are stuck.

job_title: Business Systems Analyst II in New Haven, CT
pros:
Good Healthcare
Acceptable pay
Good Retirement options
cons:
Hourly culture is stuck in the past
Low room for pay growth
Poor culture

review_title: Yale is a great place to grow with a lot of opportunities.
job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Great network of scientists and successful individuals. Yale provides a lot of opportunities for growth in many different directions as long as you can figure out what you want to do.
cons: I have nothing to say about Yale

review_title: Great place to work, especially as a student.
job_title: Office Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Supervisors great, offers amazing learning experiences, and the pay is great, especially for students on financial aid.
cons: Some students have difficulties finding positions within their preferred work environment.  Antiquated paper time sheets make it difficult to keep pay current.

job_title: Professor in New Haven, CT
pros: Great students, great facilities, pleasant surroundings, fair pay, lots of freedom, very few bad relationships, interesting tasks and surprising interactions
cons: committee work tedious; grading not fun, some administrators bad, very nasty winter weather, parking tickets easy to acquire, a few annoying regulations, but nothing really bad

job_title: Student Worker in New Haven, CT
pros: Great benefits, pay is solid relative to work/life balance, opportunity to take classes, great culture of energy and intellectual stimulation
cons: Opportunities to become senior management are limited but mobility is good elsewhere. New Haven is a small city though has most of what you need

review_title: Wish I had something better to say..
job_title: Administrative Assistant in West Haven, CT
pros: Health benefits, and alot pto, sick, personal, vacation time, well known respected professional organization. Thought would be job stability but laid off after ten years without notice
cons: No parking, reentry impossible unless you know someone on the inside, HR overloaded with liars, bs artists. Showed no compassion for unemployed, in the end was a joke.

job_title: Ops Manager, ITS in Hamden, CT
pros: Generous time off, college tuition for staff and their eligible children, on site health care, overall, good benefits.
cons: The elimination of mid level positions, resulting in the shifting of larger workloads to remaining staff, often with unreasonable expectations.

job_title: Technical Director in New Haven, CT
pros: Incredible benefits package. Significant time off. They'll fight to keep you, if you're good.
cons: Very bureaucratic. Change happens slowly, if at all. They make it hard to leave.

review_title: Don't bother with graduate school unless you love reading academic books and want desperately to be a professor.
job_title: Teaching Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros: As a grad student, you have a lot of freedom and time to travel
cons: You will be poor and disallusioned

review_title: Not much to say about a postdoc
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: University discounts are always nice, the library has great resources and takes purchase requests, most online databases are subscribed to, the Yale Health plan is pretty good
cons: New Haven is expensive, and the salary isn't good, but Yale doesn't determine either of those.

review_title: Best Student Job I Could Ask For

- Wonderful workplace environment

cons: - I honestly can't think of any right now

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Very smart and motivated people.  Amazing international and famous scientist come thru for talks.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT

job_title: Graduate Fellow in New Haven, CT
pros:
decent salary
good benefits and hours
new haven is a nice town

disorganized management
misguided administrators - for the most part
difficult to work within bureaucracy

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: A ton of labs working on a wide range of research projects
cons: Experiences sharply vary depending on the lab you're in. Some labs have happy environments and members of some labs aren't (but that's the case everywhere).

review_title: Good place to be a postdoc but please move on in couple years or you will stuck forever.
job_title: Postdoctoral  in New Haven, CT
pros: For a PostDoc in Mechanical Engineering it is a great start. Everyone notices Yale on your resume.

review_title: great place to work, very diverse
job_title: Programmer Analyst in New Haven, CT

review_title: A great place to promote yourself

A little bit disconnect with industry and job market.

review_title: Can be a good place to work, but it depends entirely on your supervisor.

Lab mates are really intelligent and we are doing interesting research.

Salary is entirely inadequate.

job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT
pros: Amazing connections to brilliant people, doing innovative work. Very humbling experience. I don't think i could have succeeded anywhere else..
cons: New Haven is insanely expensive because landlords know they have a captive student population that keeps returning to the university year after year.

job_title: Student Worker in New Haven, CT
pros: Studnet jobs pay $12 minimum which makes sustainable income even if you work part-time. Positive experience in office settings and others.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT

review_title: The expect a lot out of you, but overall a positive experience.
job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT

review_title: Typical graduate student research assistant experience

review_title: A good place to work in an academic world

Good hours, good money.

Access to DVD's, books.

review_title: Outstanding Opportunity to Work With Great People

review_title: Yale University is a great place to work, but they'll promote people just to avoid dealing with them.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Awesome benefits- great place to start a career. Great people, happy employees.

review_title: Great people and opportunities for advancement
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT

job_title: Student LIbrarian in New Haven, CT

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New Haven, CT

job_title: Project Administrator in New Haven, CT

job_title: Graduate Student in New Haven, CT

Students don't have much of a say in things.

job_title: Associate Research Scientist in New Haven, CT
pros: Collaborating with the brilliant scientists that work there is a huge plus.

job_title: in New Haven, CT

review_title: Yale Center for International and Professional Experiences

job_title: Postdoctoral Scientist in New Haven, CT

job_title: in New Haven, CT

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in New Haven, CT

Exceptional employee service perfect health insurance system.

great people and co worker

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New Haven, CT

review_title: fantastic school and resources, not great people!

job_title: Postgraduate Researcher in New Haven, CT

job_title: in New Haven, CT

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in New Haven, CT

review_title: Mostly through science PhD, fairly content
